name: English Learning Fundamentals
desc: Our EL Fundamental courses start with English Language Starters where students are first introduced to the English alphabet & short vowel sounds, advancing through our Phonics course focused on long vowels & consonant blends, and completing in our Foundations course where students can confidently read & write simple sentences.

Students engage in various learning activities, practice reading / listening / speaking / writing, refine their fine motor skills, and are exposed to social learning through designed interactions with their peers.

strings: Alphabet recognition and application
Short vowel sounds
Long vowel sounds
Consonant blends
Reading using digraphs
Basic reading & writing of 3~4 letter monosyllabic words
Fly Phonics 1 to 4: Phonic series that cover the alphabet & sounds, short & long vowels, and consonant blends & digraphs.

Reading Sketch Starters 1 to 3: To apply basic phonic knowledge to practical reading application, the Reading Sketch Starter series support fundamental phonics learning through visual stories and exciting themes.
Reading Sponge: Next in the NE Build & Grow series, this reading book supports advanced phonic learners and prepares our students to transition into the regular EL program.

name: English Learning 1-4
desc: Our EL 1 to 4 courses aim to develop the core language skills; Reading, Listening, Speaking, and Writing. Each level has been aligned to the US Common Core State Standards to provide rigorous standards and support advance English learning.

Our experienced mentors deliver engaging lessons, as well as focus on student character building, in order to support holistic learning. This focuses on the whole child as a young learner. Students maintain vocabulary journals, learn various academic skills, practice and produce from lesson objectives, and collaborate on projects.

strings: Improve reading comprehension to a US 5th grade equivalent
Recognize elements of a story
Know how to accurately summarize events, stories, and passages
Coherently express ideas in a structured and developed response
Strengthen language & writing skills

Subject Link 1 to 8: This series is used to support topic knowledge, themed/multi-disciplined learning, and improve reading comprehension. The themes are used to engage students, using their curiosity to learn specific vocabulary. The passages are used to practice reading skills and improve comprehension.

Spectrum Writing: The workbooks guide students as they write for a variety of purposes, including story-telling, personal narratives, descriptive writing, and opinion writing. This series also support current state standards, and take students through the full writing process; planning, drafting, revising, proofreading, and sharing writing.

Spectrum Language Arts: To reinforce written and spoken accuracy, the Spectrum Lannguage Arts series provides focused practice and creative activities. Students cover a variety of basic and advance language skills, such as; capitalization, punctuation, grammar, and parts of speech.

name: Life Coaching EL3
desc: The purpose of Life Coaching is to develop good habits in order to make personal growth intentional. Good habits, such as goal setting, time management, and exercise are essential for long term health and social well-being of children and teens. Our Life Coaching curriculum focuses on social, emotional, and physical well-being. We integrate lessons associated with leadership and habit building to better prepare your child for the future.

In the EL3 Life Coaching course, mentors will work with your child to build self confidence, motivation, and empathy. This course uses a mindfulness and experiential approach to learning. Teachers use real world scenarios to nurture a positive mindset and begin to develop foundational skills for leadership such as critical thinking and creativity. Ultimately, students will learn the building blocks to develop good habits and create long term goals for personal growth.

strings:
General Course Structure:
  • 30% Exercise and wellness (exercise in the gym)
  • 30% Academically focused (reading, leadership speech, writing)
  • 40% Leadership focused (teambuilding, concepts, activities)

Course Outcomes:
  • Leadership speeches
  • Exercise for 30 minutes each class
  • Focused leadership vocabulary per week
  • Focus on understanding self and good habit building
  • Daily journal completion

Physical Education:
  • Initial, Mid-Term, and Final Fitness Test
  • 30 minutes of exercise each week (sit ups, squats, running, etc.)
  • Rowing challenges
  • Mindfulness Concepts: Meditation, Yoga, and Nutrition
7 Habits of Happy Kids by Sean Covey
Point Avenue Daily Journal

name: Engineering
desc: Engineering is an interdisciplinary branch which requires a practical approach in applying learned knowledge to real life situations. At Point Avenue, our Engineering program incorporates activities that are based on existing technologies and problems. These activities will allow students to understand the connections between related areas in math and science.

Our program will introduce concepts from multiple fields of Engineering: Aerospace, Biomedical, Civil, Environmental, Chemical, Mechanical, Electrical, and Agricultural Engineering.  Students will be given the opportunity to learn and explore these fields with hands-on activities, games, and projects.

strings: Beginner: Develop a curiosity and a foundational interest for basic engineering concepts through empirical exploration
Intermediate: Develop confidence through theoretical and empirical learning of major engineering disciplines. Examine problems through an iterative mindset

name: Coding
desc: Computer science skills are becoming more relevant in all aspects of society, and students with these skills, such as coding and basic robotics, are learning them at earlier ages.

At Point Avenue, we’ve curated coding and robotics lessons for students ages 8-12, with EL3-4 level English proficiency, that are able to bring their own laptops or tablets to class. This course is great for the beginner to intermediate level coder.

strings: Understand the fundamentals of coding with a coding resource (e.g. Kamibot, the world’s first programmable paper robot).
Students will come to understand computer programming principles and also improve their focus, perseverance, and resilience.

Students will learn CoffeeScript, a programming language that is used in web applications and compiled to JavaScript. JavaScript is the industry standard for web applications, and one of the most highly sought after proficiencies for programming languages.
Students will also study Scratch, a block coding language developed by MIT.
They will apply these skills all while iterating: learning from their mistakes, and building their foundational knowledge to create something new.

name: Life Coaching EL4
desc: The purpose of Life Coaching is to develop good habits in order to make personal growth intentional. Good habits, such as goal setting, time management, and exercise are essential for long term health and social well-being of children and teens.Our Life Coaching curriculum focuses on social, emotional, and physical well-being. We integrate lessons associated with leadership and habit building to better prepare your child for the future.

This course is focused on more advanced self-development techniques including: emotional and physical health, social responsibility, and understanding psychology. Mentors guide students to develop strong core values that will help them navigate social situations. Basic life-skills, such as effective study strategies, career development, money management and community outreach are discussed.

strings:
General Course Structure:
  • 30% Exercise and wellness (exercise in the gym)
  • 30% Academically focused (reading, leadership speech, writing)
  • 40% Leadership focused (teambuilding, concepts, activities)

Course Outcomes:
  • 3Leadership speeches and soft skill development
  • 7-8 focused leadership vocabulary per week
  • 5 leadership challenge completions
  • Foundational components of brain function
  • Focus on understanding self and the senses (sight, sound, smell, taste, touch)

Physical Education:
  • Initial, Mid-Term, and Final Fitness Test
  • 30 minutes of exercise each week (sit ups, squats, running, etc.)
  • Rowing challenges
  • Mindfulness Concepts: Meditation, Yoga, and Nutrition

Mind Up Curriculum
MindUP gives children the knowledge and tools they need to manage stress, regulate emotions and face the challenges of the 21st century with optimism, resilience and compassion.
Point Avenue Daily Journal

name: English Language Arts Foundations
desc: This course is the first level in our Middle School ELA curriculum.
This course is designed for students who are learning the foundations and basic of English.
This course focuses on English fundamentals and helps with fluency, grammar, spelling, and basic sentence structure.
This course acts as a bridge to the ELA beginner course.

Pathways is National Geographic Learning's new five-level academic skills series that features reading & writing and listening & speaking strands to help learners develop the language skills needed to achieve academic success.
Learners develop academic literacy skills through content, images and videos from National Geographic.
This innovative series provides learners with a pathway to success!
Students Will:
Develop academic literacy skills
Connect to the real world through content from National Geographic
Achieve academic success

strings:
Our ELA courses help students master the essential skills required for high school, college, career, and life in today’s global economy through adhering to United States Common Core Standards.
Students advance through the four levels of ELA from Foundations to ELA Advanced.
Students will be placed based on a diagnostic assessment which focuses on reading, writing, speaking, and listening proficiency.

The ELA standards align with college expectations in 6 domains
1) Language (conventions, knowledge, vocabulary)
2) Reading: Informational (ideas, details, structure, range, text complexity)
3) Reading: Literature (ideas, details, structure, range, text complexity)
4) Reading: Foundational (concepts, phonological awareness, recognition, fluency)
5) Speaking and Listening (comprehension, collaboration, presentation)
6) Writing (type, purpose, production, distribution, research, range of writing)
National Geographic Pathways Foundations
Reading & Writing / Speaking & Listening

Pathways is a global five-level academic English program. Carefully-guided lessons develop the language skills, critical thinking, and learning strategies required for academic success. Using authentic and relevant content from National Geographic, Pathways prepares students to work effectively and confidently in an academic environment.

name: English Language Arts Beginner
desc: Designed for students who have a minimal foundation with English language fundamentals involving reading, writing, listening, and speaking.
Students at this level can communicate in English at a low level of fluency, requiring constant corrections and prompting.
The goal is to have students hold basic conversations without assistance.
A heavy focus will be placed on appropriate grammatical conventions and vocabulary expansion.

Pathways is National Geographic Learning's new five-level academic skills series that features reading & writing and listening & speaking strands to help learners develop the language skills needed to achieve academic success.
Learners develop academic literacy skills through content, images and videos from National Geographic.
This innovative series provides learners with a pathway to success!
Students Will:
Develop academic literacy skills
Connect to the real world through content from National Geographic
Achieve academic success

strings: Our ELA courses help students master the essential skills required for high school, college, career, and life in today’s global economy through adhering to United States Common Core Standards. Students advance through the four levels of ELA from Foundations to ELA Advanced. Students will be placed based on a diagnostic assessment which focuses on reading, writing, speaking, and listening proficiency.

The ELA standards align with college expectations in 6 domains
1) Language (conventions, knowledge, vocabulary)
2) Reading: Informational (ideas, details, structure, range, text complexity)

4) Reading: Foundational (concepts, phonological awareness, recognition, fluency)
5) Speaking and Listening (comprehension, collaboration, presentation)
6) Writing (type, purpose, production, distribution, research, range of writing)
National Geographic Pathways Level 1
Reading & Writing / Speaking & Listening

Pathways is a global five-level academic English program. Carefully-guided lessons develop the language skills, critical thinking, and learning strategies required for academic success. Using authentic and relevant content from National Geographic, Pathways prepares students to work effectively and confidently in an academic environment.

name: English Language Arts Intermediate
desc: Designed for students who have a moderate grasp of English language fundamentals involving reading, writing, listening, and speaking. Students at this level can communicate in English with some fluency, requiring some corrections and prompting. The goal is to improve articulation, word choice, comprehension and speaking/written fluidity. Focus will be placed on appropriate grammatical conventions and vocabulary expansion. Pathways is National Geographic Learning's new five-level academic skills series that features reading & writing and listening & speaking strands to help learners develop the language skills needed to achieve academic success. Learners develop academic literacy skills through content, images and video from National Geographic. This innovative series provides learners with a pathway to success!
Students Will:
Develop academic literacy skills
Connect to the real world through content from National Geographic
Achieve academic success

Students advance through the four levels of ELA from Foundations to ELA Advanced. Students will be placed based on a diagnostic assessment which focuses on reading, writing, speaking, and listening proficiency.

The ELA standards align with college expectations in 6 domains
1) Language (conventions, knowledge, vocabulary)

Reading & Writing / Speaking & Listening

Pathways is a global five-level academic English program. Carefully-guided lessons develop the language skills, critical thinking, and learning strategies required for academic success. Using authentic and relevant content from National Geographic, Pathways prepares students to work effectively and confidently in an academic environment.

name: English Language Arts Advanced
desc: Designed for students who have a firm grasp of English language fundamentals involving reading, writing, listening, and speaking.
Students at this level can communicate in English at a high level of fluency, requiring little to no corrections and prompting.
The goal is to refine skills in order to communicate like native speakers.
Accelerated focus will be placed on appropriate grammatical conventions, vocabulary expansion, and the use of common idioms and phrases.

Pathways is National Geographic Learning's new five-level academic skills series that features reading & writing and listening & speaking strands to help learners develop the language skills needed to achieve academic success.
Learners develop academic literacy skills through content, images and video from National Geographic.
This innovative series provides learners with a pathway to success!

strings: Our ELA courses help students master the essential skills required for high school, college, career, and life in today’s global economy through adhering to United States Common Core Standards. Students advance through the four levels of ELA from Foundations to ELA Advanced. Students will be placed based on a diagnostic assessment which focuses on reading, writing, speaking, and listening proficiency.

The ELA standards align with college expectations in 6 domains
1) Language (conventions, knowledge, vocabulary)
2) Reading: Informational (ideas, details, structure, range, text complexity)
3) Reading: Literature (ideas, details, structure, range, text complexity)
4) Reading: Foundational (concepts, phonological awareness, recognition, fluency)
5) Speaking and Listening (comprehension, collaboration, presentation)
6) Writing (type, purpose, production, distribution, research, range of writing)
National Geographic Pathways Level 3
Reading & Writing / Speaking & Listening

Pathways is a global five-level academic English program. Carefully-guided lessons develop the language skills, critical thinking, and learning strategies required for academic success. Using authentic and relevant content from National Geographic, Pathways prepares students to work effectively and confidently in an academic environment.

name: Pages (Reading Comprehension)
desc: In the age of information, it is crucial to understand how to draw meaning from what you read.
Pages is a quest for enlightenment and captivation for students, as their personal capacity for critical and analytical thinking unveils.
Young minds commit themselves to the vigorous reading and exploration of real-life and fictional literary texts to strengthen their comprehension level, reading speed, and interest in literature.
Through stimulating questions and expertly led discussions, this course helps students conquer their fear of reading and become confident, competent book lovers.
In addition to putting their language skills, self-expression and reasoning into action, students enhance their power to carefully listen to and consider the views of others.
Towards the end of the journey, a more mindful young person emerges who is better able to articulate opinions based on textual references and with the confidence to be heard.

strings:
1) To improve Lexile measures (reading proficiency scores) by helping students
  • Identify the various elements of literature, including plot, theme, setting, mood, etc.
  • Distinguish between text types by understanding how word choice, structure, and tone may vary according to the purpose and genre of literature.
  • Develop critical and analytical thinking skills by deconstructing character development, cause-and-effect relationships, symbols, foreshadowing techniques, and author’s bias or perspective.

2) To increase reading speed by helping students
  • Improve reading speed by learning skimming and scanning techniques, and how to read with purpose.
  • Improve reading comprehension by discovering specialized reading strategies to understand texts better, which will ultimately lead to increased reading speed.

3) To get students to read a minimum of 2 books in 12 weeks, along with helping them develop an interest in reading by
  • Practicing sustained silent reading, reading as a class, and facilitating discussions on what is read.

Students will be provided with acces to the Renaissance myON® Reader. A personalized digital library at every student's fingertips, Renaissance myON® Reader is a student-centered, personalized literacy environment that gives students access to more than 6,000 enhanced digital books. Titles are dynamically matched to each individual student's interests, grade and Lexile® reading level.

name: Writing Coach
desc: Point Avenue’s Ink program is designed to develop and grow students academic and creative writing skills.

The primary goal of the Ink course is to help students build foundational writing skills through western and contemporary teaching styles, and foster the important 21st century skills of creative and critical thinking.
Academic and creative writing styles, two core components of this course, complement each other in exercising different thought processes and methods for conveying messages in written format.
Students will focus on refining the communication of resources - both known and assumed fact (academic) as well as create original written content (creative).
The course texts (National Georgraphic and Word Roots) serve as a resource and guide in order to facilitate proper writing fundamentals.
This course will also strive to develop a love of writing for students through choosing interesting topics related to their interests and passions.

strings:
1) Develop the ability to write different paragraph forms
  • Understand opinion writting, sequence writing, topic sentences, conclusing sentences
  • Leardn how to write process, narrative, descriptive, and opinion papers

2) Improve grammar and overall sentence structure
  • Students will use the software platform Quill to practice grammar and track their progress throughout the term.
  • Use Focused Correction Areas (FCA's) to analyze improvement areas in their writing

3) Increase vocabulary and comprehension
  • Understand and use appropriate prefixes, suffixes using the Word Roots curriculum
  • Learn new words each week to incorporate in their writing

4) Develop a genuine interest in writing
  • We aim to create a student centric environment promoting writing topics related to student interests and passions

National Geographic Great Writing Series
The Great Writing Series uses clear explanations and extensive practical activities to help students write great sentences, paragraphs, and essays. Each book contains a wide variety of writing models in carefully selected rhetorical styles that provide practice in working with the writing process to develop a final piece of writing.

Word Roots Book Series
These award-winning books teach the meaning and spelling of roots, prefixes, and suffixes that are the elements used to form words in English. Learning these word elements dramatically improves spelling and the ability to decode unfamiliar words.

name: Life Coaching Beginner/Intermediate
desc: The Life Coaching Beginner/Intermediate course focuses on aspects of growing up, developing good habits, and creating a growth mindset. In this course, students will use the book 7 Habits of Highly Effective teens to learn life skills that will make their transition into young adulthood easier and give them confidence, decisiveness, and the ability to critique themselves in order to constantly evolve and grow. Students will work on their overall confidence by practicing public speaking, doing weekly exercises, and engaging in leadership challenges. This course is a mixture of health and wellness, academic competency, and leadership principles. After completing this course, students will be able to enroll in the Life Coaching Advanced course. Life Coaching Advanced includes more complex leadership concepts and principles meant to further develop your child into a future leader.

strings: Weekly Fitness (60 minutes each week)
Develop soft skills (posture, eye contact, confidence)
Understanding of foundational leadership principles
Leadership speeches
Daily journal writing
Teamwork and teambuilding challenges
Social and Emotional well-being
Develop a growth mindset

7 Habits of Highly Effective Teens Textbook and Workbook by Sean Covey
In the book, Covey discusses how teenagers can become more independent and effective by following seven basic habits. The habits range from being proactive in every aspect of one's life to planning and prioritizing one's daily life and responsibilities

Point Avenue Daily Journal
For this course, each student is required to maintain a journal that we supply them. Inside they are to keep track of daily goals, notable events, lessons learned, and things they are grateful for. The purpose of these journals is to measure effort in making personal growth intentional, as well as to teach students daily self-reflection in order for them to improve and grow their perspectives.

name: Life Coaching Advanced
desc: The Life Coaching Advanced course focuses on aspects of self-awareness, mindfulness, and community service. In this course, students will learn about mindfulness skills and concepts through a step-by-step process, focusing on understanding themselves and others when making decisions and acquiring knowledge. This course establishes a foundation for critical thinking skills for students to build upon as they prepare for high school and beyond. Key example lessons include: focused awareness, sharpening the senses (mindful taste, touch, smell, sight), optimism, gratitude, and kindness. In addition to MindUP, students will plan a community service activity, exercise each week for 60 minutes, and complete a daily journal.

strings: Weekly fitness (60-70 minutes each week)
Develop soft skills (posture, eye contact, confidence)
Social and Emotional Well being concepts
Mindfulness Activities
Daily Journal Writing (track progress)
1 community service project plan and presentation

MindUP Curriculum
MindUP gives children the knowledge and tools they need to manage stress, regulate emotions and face the challenges of the 21st century with optimism, resilience and compassion.

Point Avenue Daily Journal
For this course, each student is required to maintain a journal that we supply them. Inside they are to keep track of daily goals, notable events, lessons learned, and things they are grateful for. The purpose of these journals is to measure effort in making personal growth intentional, as well as to teach students daily self-reflection in order for them to improve and grow their perspectives.

name: Elementary Debate (Beginner)
desc: Point Avenue’s Elementary Debate (Beginner) course introduces students to Public Speaking and the basic concepts used in Debate. They will be provided with and apply techniques that will help them to communicate effectively, enhance their critical thinking, and deliver an engaging speech to an audience. Students will be coached on how to research and discuss a variety of topics to enhance their understanding and be given ample opportunities to offer their own opinion. Also, students will be challenged to explore and support opinions that differ from their own.

strings: Define Debate and identify related elementary-level vocabulary
Demonstrate enhanced critical thinking
Write and deliver an organized speech
Collaborate and communicate with their peers

Speakers’ Club - Public Speaking for Young People: includes practical ideas and fun activities, introduces valuable public speaking skills, and reinforces the need for preparation and attention to detail to deliver a successful speech.
Debate Pro Junior - Book 1: designed to introduce students to a variety of topics and teach them how to present opinions about these topics

name: Elementary Debate (Intermediate)
desc: Point Avenue’s Elementary Debate (Intermediate) course is designed to build upon the skills developed during the Beginner course and introduce students to more challenging Debate vocabulary and topics. Students will continue to develop their critical thinking and learn to think more creatively through brainstorming, enabling them to become powerful and deliberate communicators. Students will also be gradually introduced to more complex debating styles with a particular focus on World Schools Debating Championships (WSDC) and Asian Parliamentary (AP) formats.

strings: Demonstrate understanding of Debate and its practical applications
Express their opinion using the Argumentation and Refutation structure
Use brainstorming techniques to generate ideas, and communicate their opinion
Demonstrate critical thinking, creativity and ability to collaborate with others
Debate Pro Junior - Book 2: designed to introduce students to more advanced topics and vocabulary. Students will learn how to organize and present convincing arguments about these topics.

name: Middle & High School Debate (Beginner)
desc: Point Avenue’s Middle & High School Debate (Beginner) is a course that aims to nurture future leaders and their ability to think critically, collaborate, express and share their ideas in a powerful manner. Throughout the term, students will be exposed to a variety of debating styles, with a particular focus on World Schools Debating Championships (WSDC) and Asian Parliamentary (AP) formats.

strings: Define the purpose and structure of competitive Parliamentary Debating
Express their opinions using the Argumentation and Refutation structure
Distinguish the different roles and responsibilities of the First, Second, Third, and Reply Speaker
Utilize two brainstorming techniques in generating ideas: the Need Practicality Impact (NPI) Analysis and Stakeholder Analysis
Collaborate with their classmates in a tournament structure

Debate For All - Introduction to Debate: explores the basics of the academic sport of debate to include 21st-Century Skills, parliamentary debate format, argumentation, refutation, speaker roles, and methods of brainstorming

name: Middle & High School Debate (Intermediate)
desc: Point Avenue’s Middle & High School Debate (Intermediate) is a course designed to nurture future leaders to think critically, collaborate, express themselves creatively, and communicate their ideas effectively in a formal setting. Building on skills learned in the Middle & High School Debate (Beginner) course, students will refine their argumentation and refutation skills, learn and practice higher-level debate skills, analyze current topics, and develop effective collaboration skills with peers.

strings: Deepen their understanding of competitive Parliamentary Debate
Enhance their skills through personalized speech and case analysis drills
Exhibit logical arrangement of ideas in writing and speech
Increase their knowledge of current events and learn ways to incorporate them into formal debate speeches
Collaborate with their classmates in a tournament structure
Prepare to participate in competitive debating championships online and offline

Point Avenue Debate Topics: introduces students to various topics and presents multiple controversies around the subject. These packets aim to help students grow their general knowledge and identify the core clashes in a debate. Discussion questions ignite students' critical thinking and expand their vocabulary related to the topics.

name: Debate All Stars
desc: The Debate “All-Stars” Program is an advanced course designed for students with competitive debating tournament experience. Each class will culminate in performance assignments that require students to demonstrate their abilities and apply course content within the classroom setting. Opportunities to take their knowledge beyond the classroom are available with tournaments in and out of Vietnam and Thailand.

Possible tournaments for the students to participate in are the Vietnam Schools Debating Championship, Hanoi Debate Tournament, Asia Debate Open (China, Vietnam), Asian World Schools Debating Championship (Thailand), Oldham Cup (Singapore), Korea Youth Debating Championship (Korea), Harvard College World Schools Invitational (USA), and more.

strings: Students will be briefed on motions from previous international schools-level tournaments and create their own case files.

Students will be introduced to various debate strategies with a focus on team collaboration. For aspiring champions, the ability to communicate clearly with others on a team and collaborate towards a common goal is essential.

name: SSAT
desc: The SSAT is an academic readiness test intended to measure a student’s critical reading, quantitative reasoning, and writing skills needed for academic success at the high school level.
Enrollment Prerequisites
IELTS band 6.5 / TOEFL score of 80
SAT diagnostic result of 900
Skills Acquired
Quantitative Reasoning: algebra, geometry, measurement, and data analysis and probability.
Reading Comprehension questions evaluate a student’s ability to identify main ideas, themes, tone, and to understand the author’s purpose.
Verbal Reasoning tests vocabulary and the ability to relate ideas through identifying synonyms and interpreting analogies.
Continuation Roadmap & Options
Admissions Consulting / Boarding school admission
IELTS / TOEFL
SAT
IGCSE

strings:
SSAT Upper 101
SSAT 101 is an intensive introductory course, familiarizing students with the test and all of the essential skills they will need. The course emphasizes vocabulary expansion, critical reading & analysis, and successfully interpreting word problems and SSAT match concepts.

SSAT Upper 201 (1500 - 1950)
Students who complete 101 and haven’t yet reached their target score will move into 201. At this level, students will focus on increasing their endurance and honing the skills and strategies they learned in 101 through review and heavy practice. Students will be guided to master more challenging academic reading texts and verbal reasoning concepts.

SSAT Upper 301 (1950+)
301 follows the same principles as 201, with less emphasis on learning skills and more emphasis on focused practice, building endurance, and filling the final gaps in students’ test understanding and mastery.
Barron’s SSAT/ISEE: High School Entrance Examinations (Fourth Edition)
Kaplan SSAT & ISEE Middle & Upper Level Prep 2020
The Princeton Review Cracking the SSAT and ISEE

name: TOEFL
desc: Point Avenue's TOEFL program prepares students for official language assessment by immersing students in interpersonal communication processes. This course develops students to be more fluent, coherent, and effective multi-skilled communicators by utilizing the four assessed TOEFL skills as catalysts for language advancement. Enrollment Prerequisites
Completed ELA Intermediate or equivalent
IELTS band 5
TOEFL score of 60
Skills Acquired
Language proficiency requirements for undergraduate study
Academic vocabulary expansion
Grammatical proficiency and awareness
Listening efficacy & accuracy
Reading rate, accuracy, and critical comprehension
Speaking coherency & fluency
Writing efficacy, coherency, and cohesiveness
Interpersonal communication soft-skills
Continuation Roadmap & Options
SAT / ACT / SSAT

strings: TOEFL Junior course approaches test preparation by immersing students in the processes of interpersonal English language communication. By utilizing the assessed TOEFL skills - Reading Comprehension, Listening Comprehension, Language Form and Meaning, Writing, and Speech - as catalysts for language development, this class will offer students guidance in cultivating critical thinking, subject expertise, and tried & tested test-taking strategies, growing into more eloquent and effective multi-skilled communicators.

Pre- TOEFL: Point Avenue's program prepares students for official language assessment by immersing students in interpersonal communication processes. This course develops students from age 12-15 in to be more fluent, coherent, and effective multi-skilled communicators by utilizing the four assessed TOEFL skills as catalysts for language advancement.

TOEFL 101 (Beginner) is a foundational course for students who score between 60-80 on the diagnostic test. The primary focus of TOEFL 101 is to expand students' academic vocabulary, specific skill knowledge, and subsequent topic awareness. Each section of the class is taught using an integrated approach to reflect the official test format. Upon completion, students will be able to:
Effectively outline and map reading passages.
Understand the structure and flow of academic conversations and lectures.
Write basic academic paragraphs.

TOEFL 201 (Intermediate) is designed for students who score between 80 to 105 on the diagnostic or official test. 201 Level courses move faster. Students will improve:
Their ability to grammatically dissect reading passages.
Increase their reading comprehension and speed
Comprehend and identify main ideas and details in the Listening section.
In addition, students will learn how to generate organized and academic speaking and writing responses promptly and how to effectively utilize various complex sentence structures on both the speaking and writing sections.

TOEFL 301 (Advanced) is designed for students who score a 105+ on a diagnostic or official assessment. This course reviews all concepts, methods, and strategies for each section. The vocabulary, reading, listening, speaking, and writing workload will be increased significantly to cultivate students' ability to score as close to a perfect score as possible. The primary focus of this course targets speaking and writing mastery.
[Delta Six] Practice Tests

name: IELTS
desc: Point Avenue's IELTS program prepares students for official language assessment by immersing students in the processes of interpersonal communication. This course develops students to be more fluent, coherent, and effective multi-skilled communicators by utilizing the four assessed IELTS skills as catalysts for language advancement. Enrollment Prerequisites
Completed ELA Intermediate or equivalent
IELTS band 5
TOEFL score of 60
Skills Acquired
Language proficiency requirements for undergraduate study
Academic vocabulary expansion
Grammatical proficiency and awareness
Listening efficacy & accuracy
Reading rate, accuracy, and critical comprehension
Speaking coherency & fluency
Writing efficacy, coherency, and cohesiveness
Interpersonal communication soft-skills
Continuation Roadmap & Options
SAT / ACT / SSAT
keyword: Focus on academic skills for IELTS

strings:
IELTS 101 (Basic User): This is an introductory level course for beginner students who test between a band 5-6 on a diagnostic and who have a CEFR A1 - A2 vocabulary and grammar foundation.
Beginner-level courses explore the Listening and Speaking (Part 1) sections of the test along with the Writing and Reading sections of the General module as an introduction to academic reading and writing. A further concentration on foundational grammatical proficiency and remedial vocabulary expansion enable general English communication development.

IELTS 201 (Independent User): This is an intermediate to upper intermediate level course for between students who score between a band 6-7 and who have a CEFR B1-B2 vocabulary and grammar proficiency.
Intermediate level courses focus on IELTS vocabulary & topic knowledge expansion, and critical reading & analysis. Students' understanding of correctly utilizing grammatical conventions when writing and speaking is also a primary focus at this level.

IELTS 301: (Proficient User): This is an advanced level course for proficient students who score above a band 7 and possess a CEFR C1-C2 vocabulary and grammar proficiency. This is a one-semester course.
Advanced level courses focus on all four skill mastery, emphasizing the Writing and Speaking sections. The advancement of writing & speaking coherency, construction, and elaboration are the primary objectives for this course. Students will learn how to utilize complex grammatical structures and academic lexical items when communicating in a written or conversational format.

[Macmillan] Effective Reading 1 & 2
[Macmillan] Destination B1 Grammar & Vocabulary
[Collins] Grammar (Pre-Intermediate)

name: SAT
desc: The SAT is a college readiness test created by ETS and owned by College Board. The SAT is typically taken by high school juniors and seniors. The SAT is intended to measure literacy, numeracy, and writing skills needed for academic success at the university level.
Enrollment Requirements:
IELTS band 6.5+ / TOEFL score of 80+
Minimum diagnostic result of 900
Continuation Roadmap & Options:
Admissions Consulting
AP & IB subject courses

strings: Advanced language proficiency requirements for undergraduate study
Academic vocabulary expansion
Analysis of grammatical conventions and accuracy
Writing efficacy, coherency, and cohesiveness
Reading rate, accuracy, and critical comprehension
Quantitative reasoning accuracy, problem-solving, and data analysis
Academic independence, resilience and test endurance
College Board
Princeton Review
Kaplan
Barron's
Khan Academy

name: AP
desc: Advanced Placement is administered by the College Board that enables high school seniors to experience introductory-level university courses and earn credits towards their diploma.

Enrollment Requirements:

Students must have completed the appropriate prerequisite or be enrolled in the interested AP course at their primary educational institution
AP Courses & Exams
World & European History
English Language & Composition
Calculus AB & BC
Continuation Roadmap & Options
Admissions Consulting TOEFL / IELTS

strings:
AP World History
Students will explore the cultural, economic, political, and social developments that have shaped the world from 1200 CE to the present. Students will analyze texts, visual sources, and other historical evidence and write essays discussing historical themes and arguments.

English Language & Composition
Students will explore the elements of argument and composition as they develop critical reading and writing skills. Students will read and analyze nonfiction works from various periods and write essays aimed at exposition, argumentation, and persuasion.

Calculus AB & BC
Students will explore the concepts, methods, and applications of differential and integral calculus, including topics such as parametric, polar, and vector functions and series. Students will learn to understand the theoretical basis and solve problems by applying their knowledge and skills.
College Board
Princeton Review
Kaplan

name: IB
desc: The International Baccalaureate Diploma Program offers challenging one-year and two-year pre-university courses for students in the 11th and 12th grades. Courses require a student’s total commitment to completing all assessment components and examinations. Both Standard Level (SL) and Higher Level (HL) courses receive advanced-level credit (7 point grade scale).
Enrollment Requirements:
Students must have completed the appropriate pre-requisite or be enrolled in the interested IB course at their primary educational institution.
IB Courses & Exams
Biology
Chemistry
Mathematics
Continuation Roadmap & Options
Admissions Consulting
TOEFL / IELTS
SAT

strings:
IB assessment procedures measure the extent to which students have mastered advanced academic skills in fulfilling these goals, for example:
Analysing and presenting information
Evaluating and constructing arguments
Solving problems creatively

Basic skills are also assessed, including:
Retaining knowledge
Understanding key concepts
Applying standard methods
In addition to academic skills, DP assessment encourages an international outlook and intercultural skills, wherever appropriate
Student results are determined by performance against set standards, not by each student's position in the overall rank order
International Baccalaureate

name: IGCSE
desc: The International General Certificate of Secondary Education is a two-year program leading to externally set, marked, and certificated examinations from the University of Cambridge. Any student who takes an IGCSE subject will be gaining a qualification that is recognized globally. They are established qualifications that keep pace with educational developments and trends and so are an ideal foundation for higher-level courses such as AS and A-Levels and the International Baccalaureate Diploma. Students typically sit seven to nine subjects in one session at the end of Year 11.
Courses Offered
English Literature
History
Mathematics
Chemistry
Biology
Enrollment Requirements
Students must have completed the appropriate pre-requisite or be enrolled in the interested IGCSE course at their primary educational institution.

strings:
Skills Acquired
  • Subject knowledge expansion
  • Applying new knowledge and understanding to familiar and new situations
  • Intellectual inquiry & exploration
  • Flexibility and responsiveness to change
  • Working and communicating in English
  • Influencing outcomes
  • Cultural awareness
  • Cultural awareness
